repnme.cdata!:
India - Agricultural Human Resources
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and institutional
            development impacts substantial. Lessons learned from the
            project are conveyed as follows. Public institutional
            investments, when focused on building human capital, deliver
            positive, catalytic effects; that is, changes in staff
            motivation, commitment, and re-orientation of attitudes
            towards work were reported in the project's State
            Agricultural University, and line departments'
            activities, and, currently, these institutions are using
            organizational resources more effectively. However,
            complementarity between capacity enhancement, and reform
            incentives are important factors, to be engaged in project
            design, with issues of internal performance incentives,
            wherever human capital investments are made. Furthermore, to
            sustain performance-related behavioral changes, the main
            goal of the project, the presence of durable constituencies
            for reform is required, following implementation and when
            supervisions cease. But creation of such constituencies
            require delegation, decentralization, and empowerment of
            various functionaries, as well as institutionalization of
            key reforms, and, project design needs to devise ways to
            initiate, and elicit such governance, and institutional
            reform, probably by phasing in project investments,
            explicitly linked to the realization of agreed
            "milestones" of governance reform. Other lessons
            address the need for strong monitoring and evaluation
            systems, clear objectives, timely training, and
            capacity-related activities, and integrated financial
            management, and procurement inputs.

18157648.trustfund:
TF020385-AGRICULTURAL HUMAN RESOURCES DEV.,TF029475-PHRD-UTTAR PRADESH DIVERSIFIED
            AGRIC. SUPPORT PROJ.,TF031386-INDIA - AGRICULTURE HUMAN
            RESOURCE DEV.,TF020761-AUSTRALIAN CONSULTANTS TRUST

repnme.cdata!:
India - Agricultural Human Resources
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Agriculture Human Resource
            Development Project will introduce meaningful changes in the
            way the Center and the states develop and emply human
            resources with the aim to make them, and thereby the sector,
            more productive. To achieve these changes, policy and
            institutional reforms will be carried out. The project will
            also foster changes in investment priorities resulting from
            policy and institutional reforms adopted. The project will
            begin a process of: a) improving the quality and relevance
            of higher agricultural education and in-service training
            programs; and b) strengthening the capacity of participating
            states to develop and manage agricultural human resources.
            The five year project will be the first phase in a long-term
            program to improve agricultural human resources development.
            Each state will carry out university programs encompassing:
            a) curriculum and syllabus reform; b) faculty quality
            improvement; c) revitalization of teaching methodologies; d)
            faculty exchanges within India and with foreign
            universities; e) modernization of university administration
            and management systems; f) upgrading of teaching laboratory
            equipment; and g) establishment of placement centers and
            student attachment programs to agroindustries. To upgrade
            human resource management at the state level, the project
            will support: 1) in-service human resources development and
            management programs; and 2) manpower needs assessment.
